importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the article's update, signaling a shift in the administration's stance on a potential Trump-Putin summit, reflecting current diplomatic developments.
This date marks the day when the White House officially stated there were no immediate plans for a Trump-Putin summit, signaling a de-escalation in diplomatic engagement.
This date refers to the day after the Thursday phone call between Trump and Putin, when Trump expressed hope for a summit within two weeks — now deemed unlikely.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Originally, Trump envisioned a Trump-Putin summit within two weeks of a Thursday phone call, but this timeline has been effectively abandoned due to lack of progress on key issues.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: immediately following the Trump-Putin phone call
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The administration initially expected a meeting between Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov next week to lay groundwork for a Trump-Putin summit — a plan now discontinued.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump's hopes for a quick summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin have stalled, with no immediate plans for a meeting.

The White House and administration officials now say that a high-level meeting between Secretary Marco Rubio and Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov is no longer necessary, due to divergent expectations on ending the war in Ukraine.
Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov is seen as a loyalist to Putin but not a decision-maker, limiting his role in advancing diplomatic progress.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky argues that Russia's lack of interest in diplomacy is tied to the US refusal to provide Ukraine with long-range Tomahawk missiles, suggesting that long-range capabilities are a key factor in achieving peace.
Trump continues to advocate for an end to the war by stopping it at the battle line, a position supported by European leaders and Ukraine.
The Kremlin claims no summit date was set, and thus cannot be postponed, emphasizing that a scheduled meeting is required to proceed.
A possible future meeting between Rubio and Lavrov could take place at an ASEAN-led global summit in Malaysia next week, though it remains uncertain.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the narrative, as his original proposal for a Trump-Putin summit has stalled, reflecting shifts in U.S. foreign policy and diplomatic priorities.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the counterpart to Trump in the proposed summit, and the article highlights the lack of progress in diplomatic engagement between the two leaders.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio was expected to meet with Lavrov to lay groundwork for a Trump-Putin summit, but this has been dropped due to misalignment in views on ending the war in Ukraine.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is seen as a loyalist to Putin with limited influence on major policy decisions, which undermines the potential for meaningful progress in negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky criticizes Russia’s reduced interest in diplomacy and links it to the U.S. withholding long-range missiles, suggesting a direct link between military capabilities and peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov defends the Kremlin’s position that a summit cannot be postponed without a scheduled date, reinforcing the lack of formal planning for a Trump-Putin meeting.

namedEntities.name: Anna Kelly
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kelly emphasizes Trump’s ongoing commitment to peace in Ukraine, reinforcing the administration’s stated position despite the stalled summit plans.

namedEntities.name: Mark Rutte
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is scheduled to meet Rutte at the White House, indicating ongoing diplomatic engagements within Western alliances even as the Trump-Putin summit stalls.

namedEntities.name: ASEAN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ASEAN is proposed as a venue where Rubio and Lavrov might meet in the future, suggesting a potential alternative path for diplomatic dialogue.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump’s hopes for a swift summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin have collapsed, as the administration now states there are no immediate plans for such a meeting. This follows a previous announcement that a summit would happen within two weeks after a phone call between the two leaders. Officials say that Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov had a productive but inconclusive call, with divergent views on ending Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Lavrov, viewed as a loyalist to Putin without real decision-making power, is seen as ineffective in advancing negotiations. Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky blames the U.S. withholding long-range missiles for Russia’s reduced interest in diplomacy, suggesting that enhanced Ukrainian capabilities are key to ending the war. The Kremlin maintains that no date was set for the summit and thus cannot be postponed. While the direct Trump-Putin meeting is on hold, diplomatic efforts may continue through side meetings at a future ASEAN-led global summit in Malaysia.
title: Trump’s hopes for quick second summit with Putin have stalled out
